article.subtitle: Worksheet 14 - Line integrals of real valued functions

abstract.p: This worksheet is meant to be used in class. You should be working in groups or individually depending on the instructions from your teacher.
You can submit responses any number of times.

Remember, the point is that you learn from your mistakes and with the help of your peers, so make sure you reflect on incorrect answers and try again with your new understanding. If you can't figure it out, ask your teacher, or bring up your strategy in a whole class discussion. This will allow you to get as much as possible out of the activity.

exercises.title: (**) Exercises
exercises.p: The following exercises test your knowledge of the prerequisites for this section.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the line segment from the point (1,2) to the point (-1,3).
\vec{r}(t) = for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that a vector equation for a line segment from point P to point Q is \vec{r}(t)=\vec{P} +\vec{PQ}t for 0\leq t\leq 1 where \vec{P} is the position vector with head at point P and \vec{PQ} is the vector pointing from P to Q.

solution.p: The vector pointing from (1,2) to (-1,3) is \vec{v}=-2\vec{i} +\vec{j}. Therefore, a vector equation for this line segment will be \vec{r}(t)=\vec{i} +2\vec{j} +(-2\vec{i} +\vec{j})t=(1-2t)\vec{i} +(2+t)\vec{j} with 0\leq t\leq 1.
There are many other correct answers.

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the half circle (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=4 with y\geq -2 oriented counter-clockwise.
for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0).

solution.p: Observe that (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=4 is a circle of radius 2 centered at (1,-2). The equation \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle of radius 1 oriented counter-clockwise starting at (1,0) when t=0. To get a circle of radius 2, we scale each component by 2, and to move the center to (1,-2) we add the vector \vec{i} -2\vec{j} (which translates every point to the right by 1 and down by 2). Thus \vec{r}(t) =(2\cos t +1)\vec{i} +(2\sin t -2)\vec{j} for 0\leq t\leq 2\pi is a circle of radius 2 centered at (1,-2) oriented counterclockwise starting at (3,-2) when t=0. To get the half circle, we restrict 0\leq t\leq \pi.

statement.p: Which of the following are also parametric equations the same half-circle?

hint.p: Recall that \vec{r}(t) =\cos t \vec{i} +\sin t \vec{j}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi gives a full circle oriented counter-clockwise starting (when t=0) at (1,0). What does replacing t by 2t do in the parameterization \vec{r}(t) ?

solution.p: \vec{r}(t) =(2\cos(2t)+1)\vec{i} +(2\sin(2t)-2)\vec{j}, for 0\leq t\leq \pi/2

statement.p: Find a vector equation for the portion of the parabola y=2x^2-1 from x=-1 to x=2.
\vec{r}(t) = for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that to parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x), we can choose x=t and then y is completely determined by the function y=f(x).

solution.p: To parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function y=f(x), we can choose x=t and then we get y=f(t)=2t^2-1. Thus, \vec{r}(t) =t\vec{i} +(2t^2-1)\vec{j} is a vector equation for y=2x^2-1. Since x=t we choose -1 \leq t\leq 2 to restrict to the appropriate domain.

statement.p: Find parametric equations for the curve x=\sin{y} for 0\leq y\leq 2\pi.
\vec{r}(t) = for \leq t \leq

hint.p: Recall that to parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function x=f(y), we can choose y=t and then x is completely determined by the function x=f(y).

solution.p: To parameterize a curve that follows that graph of a function x=f(y), we can choose y=t and then we get x=f(t)=\sin t. Thus, \vec{r}(t) =\sin t\vec{i} +t\vec{j} is a vector equation for x=\sin y. Since y=t we choose 0\leq t\leq 2\pi to restrict to the appropriate domain.

statement.p: Find \(\int_{C} (x^2+y^2) ds\) where \(C\) is parameterized by \(\vec{r}(t) =\cos{(t)} \vec{i} +\sin{(t)} \vec{j}\) for \(0\leq t\leq \pi\).
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.
\(\displaystyle\int_{C} (x^2+y^2) ds =\)

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function \(f(x,y)\), the integral \(\int_{C} f(x,y) ds\) is equal to \(\int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||dt\) where \(\vec{r}(t)\) parameterizes \(C\).

solution.p:
We have \(\vec{r}'(t)=-\sin{(t)} \vec{i} +\cos{(t)}\vec{j}\). Therefore
\int_{C} (x^2+y^2) ds \amp = \int_0^\pi \left((\cos t)^2+(\sin t)^2 \right) ||\vec{r}'(t)|| dt \amp = \int_0^\pi \left((\cos t)^2+(\sin t)^2 \right)\sqrt{(-\sin t)^2+(-\cos t)^2}dt \amp = \int_{0}^{\pi} 1~ dt \amp = \pi

statement.p: Find \int_{C} xyz ds where C is parameterized by \vec{r}(t) =-\cos{(t)} \vec{i} +\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin{(t)} \vec{j} -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\sin{(t)}\vec{k} for 0\leq t\leq \pi /2.
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function f(x,y), the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ds is equal to \int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||dt where \vec{r}(t) parameterizes C.

solution.p:
We have \vec{r}'(t)=\sin{(t)} \vec{i} +\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos{(t)} \vec{j} -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\cos{(t)}\vec{k}. Therefore
\int_{C} xyz ds \amp = \int_0^{\pi /2} \left(-\cos{(t)}\right)\left(- \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin{(t)} \right)\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} ||\vec{r}'(t)|| dt \amp = \int_0^{\pi /2} \cos{(t)} \sin^{2}{(t)}\sqrt{(-\sin t)^2+\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos t\right)^2+\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos t\right)^2}dt \amp = \int_0^{\pi /2} \cos{(t)} \sin^{2}{(t)}\sqrt{\sin^{2}(t) +\cos^2{(t)}}dt \amp = \int_0^{\pi /2} \cos{(t)} \sin^{2}{(t)}dt \amp = \frac{\sin^{3}({t})}{3} \bigg|_{0}^{\pi /2} \amp = \frac{1}{3}.

statement.p: Find \int_{C} (x-y) ds where C is the line segment from (1,3) to (5,-2).
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function f(x,y), the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ds is equal to \int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||dt where \vec{r}(t) parameterizes C.

solution.p:
The line segment from (1,3) to (5,-2) can be parametrized by \[\vec{r}(t)=(4t+1)\vec{i}+(-5t+3)\vec{j},\quad 0\leq t\leq 1.\] Then we have \vec{r}'(t)=4\vec{i} -5\vec{j} and so
\displaystyle\int_{C} (x-y) ds \amp = \int_0^{1} \left( (4t+1)-(-5t+3)\right) \sqrt{(4)^2+(-5)^2} dt \amp = \int_0^{1} (9t-2) \sqrt{41} dt \amp = \sqrt{41} \left( \frac{9t^2}{2} -2t\right)_{0}^{1} \amp = \frac{5\sqrt{41}}{2}.

statement.p: Find \int_{C} (z+y^2) ~ ds where C is the line segment from (3,4,0) to (1,4,2).
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function f(x,y), the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ds is equal to \int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||dt where \vec{r}(t) parameterizes C.

solution.p:
The line segment from (3,4,0) to (1,4,2) can be parametrized by \vec{r}(t)=(-2t+3)\vec{i}+4\vec{j} +(2t)\vec{k},\quad 0\leq t\leq 1. Then we have \vec{r}'(t)=-2\vec{i} +2\vec{k} and so
\int_{C} (z+y^2) ~ ds \amp = \int_0^{1} \left((2t)+(4)^2\right) \sqrt{(-2)^2+(0)^2+(2)^2} ~ dt \amp = \int_0^{1} (2t+16) \sqrt{8} ~ dt \amp =\sqrt{8} \left( t^2 +16t\right)_{0}^{1} \amp =17\sqrt{8}.

statement.p: Find \int_{C} 3x ~ ds where C is the curve y=x^2 from (0,0) to (3,9).
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function f(x,y), the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ~ ds is equal to \int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||~dt where \vec{r}(t) parameterizes C.

solution.p:
The curve y=x^2 from from (0,0) to (3,9) can be parametrized by \vec{r}(t)=t\vec{i}+t^2\vec{j},\quad 0\leq t\leq 3. Then we have \vec{r}'(t)=\vec{i} +(2t)\vec{k} and so
\int_{C} 3x ~ ds \amp = \int_0^{3} \left(3t \right) \sqrt{(1)^2+(2t)^2}~dt \amp = \int_0^{3} 3t \sqrt{1+4t^2}~dt \amp = \left( \frac{1}{4}\left(1+4t^2\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} \right)_{0}^{3} \amp = \frac{1}{4}\left( \left(37\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} -1\right).

statement.p: Find \int_{C} y ~ ds where C is the upper half of the circle of radius 2 from (2,0) to (-2,0).
Enter the exact answer or round to three decimal places.

hint.p: Recall that for a scalar valued function f(x,y), the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ~ ds is equal to \int_{C} f(\vec{r}(t)) ||\vec{r}'(t)||~dt where \vec{r}(t) parameterizes C.

solution.p:
The the upper half of the circle of radius 2 from (2,0) to (-2,0) can be parametrized by \vec{r}(t)=(2\cos t) \vec{i}+(2\sin t)\vec{j},\quad 0\leq t\leq \pi. Then we have \vec{r}'(t)=-2\sin{(t)} \vec{i} +2\cos{(t)} \vec{j} and so
\int_{C} y ds \amp = \int_0^{\pi} \left(2\sin t \right) \sqrt{(-2\sin t)^2+(2\cos t)^2}dt \amp = \int_0^{\pi} \left(2\sin t \right) \sqrt{4}dt \amp = 4\left( -\cos t \right)_{0}^{\pi} \amp = 8.

section.title: Second Problem Set
section.p: The contour diagram of a function f(x,y) is given below. Use it to answer the following question.

statement.p: (a) Find \int_{C_2} f(x,y) ~ ds exactly.
(b) Order the integrals (I)\(\int_{C_1} f(x,y) ~ ds\), (II)\(\int_{C_2} f(x,y) ~ ds\), and (III)\(\int_{C_3} f(x,y) ~ ds\).

hint.p: Recall that the integral \int_{C} f(x,y) ~ds gives the weighted area under f(x,y) above C. What do the contours that the different curves lie on tell you about these areas?

solution.p: (a) C_2 is entirely along the 0 contour so \int_{C_2} f(x,y) ds=0.

(b) We know \(\int_{C_2} f(x,y) ~ ds=0\). Since \(C_1\) lies only on positive contours, the area under \(f(x,y)\) above \(C_1\) will be positive, so \(\int_{C_1} f(x,y)~ ds\gt 0\). Similarly since \(C_3\) lies only on negative contours, the weighted area under \(f(x,y)\) above \(C_3\) will be negative (since it is below the \(xy\)-plane), so \(\int_{C_3} f(x,y)~ ds\lt 0\). Thus \int_{C_3} f(x,y) ~ds\lt \int_{C_2} f(x,y) ~ds\lt \int_{C_1} f(x,y) ~ds.

li.p: Are the following statements true or false?

ol.li: If C is a curve and -C is the same curve oriented in the opposite direction, then for any scalar function f(x,y) we have \displaystyle \int_{-C} f(x,y)ds=\displaystyle -\int_{C} f(x,y)ds .
If f(x,y)=k for some constant k , then \displaystyle \int_{C} f(x,y)ds=k|C| where |C| denotes the length of C .
The integral \displaystyle \int_{C} f(x,y)ds is always positive since it measures the area of f(x,y) over the curve C .
If C_1 is longer than C_2 , then \displaystyle \int_{C_1} f(x,y)ds>\displaystyle \int_{C_2} f(x,y)ds .
Explain geometrically why if P and Q are two different points and C_1 and C_2 are curves between them, it is not necessary that \displaystyle \int_{C_1} f(x,y)ds=\displaystyle \int_{C_2} f(x,y)ds .
If a curve C lies entirely on the contour f(x,y)=k of a function f(x,y) , what is the value of \int_{C} f(x,y)ds ?
